markdown:
<title
    level="1"
    right="Armor 0"
    pfs="Standard"
>
[Buckle Armor](/Armor.aspx?ID=18)
</title>

<traits>
<trait label="Adjusted Storage" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=468" />
<trait label="Noisy" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=205" />
</traits>

<column gap="tiny">

<row gap="tiny">**Source** [Treasure Vault](/Sources.aspx?ID=191) pg. 10 <sup>1.1</sup></row>

<row gap="medium">
**Price** 4 gp

**AC Bonus** +2

**Dex Cap** +3

**Check Penalty** -1

**Speed Penalty** —
</row>

<row gap="medium">
**Strength** 12

**Bulk** 1

**Category** Light

**Group** Leather
</row>

</column>

---

Absalom style once led famous adventurers to wear clothing with an unusual number of buckles, pouches, and straps. This fashion birthed a trend that led to “buckle armor,” a colloquial name for chic armor with spacious tool storage. Buckle armor comes with the [storage](/Equipment.aspx?ID=1825) armor adjustment.

<title level="2">Armor Specialization Effects</title>

<row gap="tiny">**Source** [Core Rulebook](/Sources.aspx?ID=1) pg. 275 <sup>4.0</sup></row>

Certain class features can grant you additional benefits with certain armors. This is called an armor specialization effect. The exact effect depends on which armor group your armor belongs to, as listed below. Only medium and heavy armors have armor specialization effects.

[Click here for the full rules on Armor Specialization Effects](/Rules.aspx?ID=211).

<document level="2" id="armor-group-3" />

<title level="2">Specific Magic Armor</title>
[Ouroboros Buckles](/Equipment.aspx?ID=1850)
name: Buckle Armor
